ocr_text: RONNIE VILLE COLLEGE LIBRARY COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT POLICY April 2024 POLICY STATEMENT This Collection Development Policy provides guidance for the acquisition, maintenance, and weeding of library materials to support the academic programs and research initiatives of Ronnie Ville College. The policy ensures systematic development of resources aligned with institutional goals and accreditation standards. PURPOSE OF THE COLLECTION Purpose of the Collection Ensure balanced collection growth across disciplines based on usage statistics and faculty recommendations. Provide access to current and authoritative information resources in all fields of study. Foster information literacy and lifelong learning through diverse formats and accessible resources. Maintain relevance through continuous evaluation, weeding, and replacement of outdated materials. ACQUISITIONS BUDGET Acquisitions Budget: The annual budget for library acquisitions is approximately ®1 562 967, allocated across print materials, electronic resources, subscriptions, and multimedia collections. Budget distribution is reviewed annually by the Library Committee in consultation with academic departments to ensure equitable resource allocation. 3. PRINT BOOKS Print Books: Priority is given to titles recommended by faculty and aligned with course syllabi Preference for authoritative publishers, peer reviewed works, and award winning titles. Multiple copies may be acquired for high demand titles based on circulation data, Materials must be published within the last five years, except for classic texts and historical references. Donated materials are evaluated against the same selection criteria and may be declined if not aligned with the collection scope. Ronnie Ville College Library Collection Development Policy Effective April 2024

ocr_text: JOHN VILLE COMMUNITY COLLEGE LIBRARY Library COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT POLICY This policy establishes the framework for selecting, acquiring, and maintaining library materials to ‘support the academic mission and research goals of the institution. It ensures balanced collection growth aligned with curricular demands, accreditation standards, and emerging scholarly trends. 1. SELECTION CRITERIA Donated materials are evaluated against the same criteria as purchased items. Selection emphasizes authoritative publishers, peer reviewed content, and award winning works. «+ Materials must directly support the curriculum and align with institutional learning outcomes, Budget allocation is reviewed annually in consultation with the Library Advisory Committee. Priority is given to resources recommended by faculty and academic departments. 1 1. INSTRUCTIONAL RESOURCES Textbooks and supplementary readings listed in official course syllabi receive highest priority. Materials for new programs are acquired at least one semester prior to program launch. Foreign language materials are acquired to support language departments and Intemational studies programs. Multimedia resources including DVDs, streaming media, and interactive tools are selected to enhance leaming Multiple copies are acquired for high enrollment courses based on usage statistics and faculty requests. Study guides, test preparation materials, and career development resources are available for student success, Open educational resources (OER) are promoted and integrated where quality and relevance are verified Faculty are encouraged to submit acquisition requests via the library portal at least 60 days in advance. «+ Course reserves are updated each semester in coordination with department heads and course instructors, 1 2 RESEARCH MATERIALS Research collections emphasize peer reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and specialized databases in core disciplines. Interibrary loan services supplement holdings for niche or rarely used materials. The library supports open access initiatives and institutional repositories to maximize the dissemination of faculty scholarship September 2025

ocr_text: STEVE VILLE COMMUNITY zi COLLEGE LIBRARY Library COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT POLICY This policy establishes the framework for selecting, acquiring, and maintaining library materials to support the academic mission and research goals of the institution. It ensures balanced collection growth aligned with curricular demands, accreditation standards, and emerging scholarly trends. 1. SELECTION CRITERIA Priority is given to resources recommended by faculty and academic departments. Materials must directly support the curriculum and align with institutional learning outcomes. Budget allocation is reviewed annually in consultation with the Library Advisory Committee. Donated materials are evaluated against the same criteria as purchased items. Selection emphasizes authoritative publishers, peer reviewed content, and award winning works. 1 1. INSTRUCTIONAL RESOURCES, Outdated editions are systematically weeded and replaced with current versions as budget permits. Faculty are encouraged to submit acquisition requests via the library portal at least 60 days in advance. Electronic versions are preferred where licensing allows simultaneous multi user access. Course reserves are updated each semester in coordination with department heads and course instructors. Study guides, test preparation materials, and career development resources are available for student success. Multimedia resources including DVDs, streaming media, and interactive tools are selected to enhance learning Textbooks and supplementary readings listed in official course syllabi receive highest priority. Reserve collections are maintained for materials with limited availability or high circulation demand. 1 2 GRADUATE RESEARCH SUPPORT Electronic journals and e books are preferred for research materials due to accessibility and space considerations. Print acquisitions focus on landmark works, reference texts, and materials unavailable in digital format. The library participates in patron driven acquisition programs to ensure relevance and immediate availability. July 2025

It ensures balanced collection growth aligned with curricular demands, accreditation standards, and emerging scholarly trends. 1. ACQUISITION GUIDELINES Donated materials are evaluated against the same criteria as purchased items. Selection emphasizes authoritative publishers, peer reviewed content, and award winning works. Materials must directly support the curriculum and align with institutional learning outcomes. Priority is given to resources recommended by faculty and academic departments. 1 1+ ACADEMIC PROGRAM SUPPORT Electronic versions are preferred where licensing allows simultaneous multi user access. Faculty are encouraged to submit acquisition requests via the library portal at least 60 days in advance. Course reserves are updated each semester in coordination with department heads and course instructors. Open educational resources (OER) are promoted and integrated where quality and relevance are verified Materials for new programs are acquired at least one semester prior to program launch. Textbooks and supplementary readings listed in official course syllabi receive highest priority. Reserve collections are maintained for materials with limited availability or high circulation demand. Multiple copies are acquired for high enrollment courses based on usage statistics and faculty requests. Foreign language materials are acquired to support language departments and intemational studies programs. Multimedia resources including DVDs, streaming media, and interactive tools are selected to enhance leaming, Outdated editions are systematically weeded and replaced with current versions as budget permits. 1 2 RESEARCH MATERIALS Electronic journals and e books are preferred for research materials due to accessibility and space considerations Print acquisitions focus on landmark works, reference texts, and materials unavailable in digital format. The library participates in patron driven acquisition programs to ensure relevance and immediate availability, April 2025,

ocr_text: FRANK VILLE POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE LIBRARY COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT POLICY This policy establishes the framework for selecting, acquiring, and maintaining library materials to support the academic mission and research goals of the institution. It ensures balanced collection growth aligned with curricular demands, accreditation standards, and emerging scholarly trends. 1. ACQUISITION GUIDELINES Priority is given to resources recommended by faculty and academic departments Selection emphasizes authoritative publishers, peer reviewed content, and award winning works Materials must directly support the curriculum and align with institutional learning outcomes. Budget allocation is reviewed annually in consultation with the Library Advisory Committee. Donated materials are evaluated against the same criteria as purchased items. 1 1. COURSE RELATED MATERIALS Electronic versions are preferred where licensing allows simultaneous multi user access. Course reserves are updated each semester in coordination with department heads and course instructors. Textbooks and supplementary readings listed in official course syllabi receive highest priority Study guides, test preparation materials, and career development resources are available for student success. Outdated editions are systematically weeded and replaced with current versions as budget permits Foreign language materials are acquired to support language departments and intemational studies programs Multimedia resources including DVDs, streaming media, and interactive tools are selected to enhance learning Open educational resources (OER) are promoted and integrated where quality and relevance are verified Reserve collections are maintained for materials with limited availabilty or high circulation demand Materials for new programs are acquired at least one semester prior to program launch 1 2 RESEARCH MATERIALS Research collections emphasize peer reviewed journals, conference proceedings, and specialized databases in core disciplines. Interlibrary loan services supplement holdings for niche or rarely used materials. The library supports ‘open access initiatives and institutional repositories to maximize the dissemination of faculty scholarship. March 2025
